description: From Early Modern English manage, menage, from Middle English *manage, *menage, from Old French manege (“the handling or training of a horse, horsemanship, riding, maneuvers, proceedings”), probably from Old Italian maneggiare (“to handle, manage, touch, treat”), ultimately from Latin manus (“the hand”); see manual.

entries.meaning: (now rare) The act of managing or controlling something.

examples: You must draw [the horse] in his career with his manage, and turn, doing the corvetto, leaping &c..

verbs.description: manage (third-person singular simple present manages, present participle managing, simple past and past participle managed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To direct or be in charge of.
(transitive) To handle or control (a situation, job).
(transitive) To handle with skill, wield (a tool, weapon etc.).
examples: It was so much his interest to manage his Protestant subjects.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To succeed at an attempt in spite of difficulty.
examples: He managed to climb the tower.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To achieve (something) without fuss, or without outside help.
examples: It's a tough job, but I'll manage.

entries.meaning: To manage to say; to say while fighting back embarrassment, laughter, etc.
To train (a horse) in the manège; to exercise in graceful or artful action.
(obsolete) To treat with care; to husband.
